Running java 1.8.0_191 on Windows 10

Rebuilt nb-10-vc1 from clean folder, where I unzipped the source zip that I downloaded.
Executed
Ant clean
Ant build
Ant tryme

During tryme, I activated sone plugins in Netbeans and the Netbeans asked to dowload version 1.4 (!) Of the nb-javac plugin.
Inside the plugin, in the ext folder, are the wrappex javac jars, but they have no version specified in their meta files.


So how do you get the 1.5 version of the plugin?

Tools: plugins : check for updates, else under settings add http://plugins.netbeans.org/nbpluginportal/updates/10.0/catalog.xml.gz 
and check for updates.

I did not review yet and I'm currently wondering if it is worth it. With the knowledge of today (underlying issue fixed in JDK, unhandled error situation newly introduced) I would not have merged it. So  I openly ask - should we just revert commits:

- f84b25e042e1a3eeb88afcc12805cd74bc5e4fd7 (first part of fix)
- 4b82e6adb31e294c74fd2fa99779ce9e27ae6184 (origin)

From my POV we are introducing much code to work-around a non-problem on recent JDKs. In one year no-one can explain what made us introduce `org.openide.util.io.FilesNI`. git revert does not fully run clean, but manually reverting should be perfectly doable.

I'll tag @mdindoffer here to get his opinion.

@matthiasblaesing I appreciate the assistance.  I've updated the files using those to which you had supplied links.  I've also modified licenseinfo.xml accordingly.  Hope this does the trick...thanks again!

Thanks for the update. I have two remaining issues:

- the licenses of the javaee-api-5.jar is not ALv2 (see the `META-INF/LICENSE.TXT` inf the file)
- the two license file `glassfish-license.txt` and `w3c-license.txt` don't belong into the `external` directory, as the corresponding files were removed. The run of `ant -Dcluster.config=enterprise verify-libs-and-licenses` should report that (the travis-ci runs currently only cover a subset of the codebase).

I also added a `.gitignore` to the module directory, so that the generated files from the XSDs are not reported as "new" files for git.

You need a build from the branch' sources. Copying the the cmdline instructions:
```
git checkout -b sdedic-jsparser_download master
git pull git://github.com/sdedic/incubator-netbeans.git jsparser_download
```
Then build and run.

This is not a fix, but a work-around. The underlying issue is either in netbeans or the JDK and we should ensure, that it gets fixed really. Forcing gtk2 as an option will quickly go away (it must be considered an implementation detail).

I would add a comment about it to the config - that way in the future some one considering removing the option knows why it is there and what needs to be done to remove it.

For the issue title: This is not Gnome 2.2, but Gtk 2.2. Gnome is a desktop environment build on top of it it is one of the users of the toolkit, but not the only one.

Well it was never a blocker, as AssertionErrors are never blockers for release (we do not enable assertions). I'd vote no for this PR in favor of #1006 which fix the real problem.

NodeActions are by default async so they are executed on RP thread instead of EDT. You need to make the NodeAction sync to overcome these kind of issues. There could be more than one, they has to be fixed in similar ways, not suppressing the original intent of this assert.

Thanks @matthiasblaesing for merging schema changes.
After these schema changes ,schema generation if failing only for glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.dtd(present inside https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/glassfish/main/appclient/gf-client-module/5.0/gf-client-module-5.0.jar) , for rest two files(sun-resources_1_3.dtd, glassfish-resources_1_5.dtd) it worked

I found out below tag is  causing the issue
< !ELEMENT enterprise-beans (name?, unique-id?, ejb*, pm-descriptors?, cmp-resource?,
	message-destination*, webservice-description*, property*) >
	
in old file tag was
< !ELEMENT enterprise-beans (name?, unique-id?, ejb*, pm-descriptors?, cmp-resource?,
	message-destination*, webservice-description*) >

If I remove attribute 'property*' , build happens successfully.
error msg is as below
incubator-netbeans/enterprise/j2ee.sun.dd/build/classes-generated/org/netbeans/modules/j2ee/sun/dd/impl/ejb/model_3_1_1/EnterpriseBeans.java:359: error: method setPropertyElement(int,PropertyElement) is already defined in class EnterpriseBeans
[nb-javac] public void setPropertyElement(int index, org.netbeans.modules.j2ee.sun.dd.api.ejb.PropertyElement value) throws VersionNotSupportedException

@arusinha @vikasprabhakar the thing we can do is to replace the XSDs is to drop Schema2Beans and use the DOM directly. Basicly the DTDs are just describing the logical structure of the config files. Consider this method (in `j2ee.jboss` model):

org.netbeans.modules.j2ee.jboss4.config.mdb.MessageDestinationSupport.modifyMessageDestinationModel(Server, String, Type)

If the destination does not yet exists:
- it creates an `mbean` element
- for this element the attributes `code` and `name` are set
- it creates a `depends` element
- for this element the attribute `optional-attribute-name` and the text-content is set (commented out due to an issue in Schema2Beans)

The most difficult part will be ensuring the order of the elements is correct.
Sounds good.

Could you please also adjust `/enterprise/j2ee.kit/test/qa-functional/src/org/netbeans/test/j2ee/Bundle.properties`? It has a GPLv2/CDDL header, which should not be there anymore.

I found it by running:

```shell
cd enterprise/j2ee.kit
grep -r CDDL *
```

That grep call can produce false positives, but it can be used to quickly assess the situation.

Sorry - I just realized, that that was the file you modified. You original change was correct, I failed to checkout the correct revision. The second commit removes the ALv2 header, which should be there.

The situation can be rectified with the CLI client:
```shell
git checkout review-j2ee.kit # switch to the branch used for the PR
git rebase -i HEAD~1 # change the first verb in the line from pick to drop, save and quit, this removes the last commit from history
git push -f          # force push, as history was changed
```

Merged - thank you.

@arusinha your finding is correct. The error message from javac gives an additional hint: The code generator generates duplicate methods. The `@Schema2Beans` annotation for the 3.1.1 model reads:

```java
@Schema2Beans(
    schema="../../resources/glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.dtd",
    schemaType=SchemaType.DTD,
    mddFile="../../resources/glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.mdd",
    outputType=OutputType.TRADITIONAL_BASEBEAN,
    docRoot="glassfish-ejb-jar",
    useInterfaces=true,
    validate=false,
    attrProp=true,
    java5=true
)
```

From there you get to the `mdd` file and in `glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.mdd` you find lines 52-85. These customize the code generation and in this case the problem is in the `user-code`. That element adds dummy methods for the `property related methods. With the correct DTD you added, the code is generated and the dummy methods are present.

Solution: Remove the whole `user-code` element from the `EnterpriseBeans` customization - lines 59-84 in `glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.mdd`. After running `ant clean` the code generator will produce sane code.

Thanks @matthiasblaesing for the solution, the build was successful
I had now commented out lines 59-84 commented out in glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.mdd and had added latest available .dtd files(glassfish-ejb-jar_3_1-1.dtd,sun-resources_1_3.dtd, glassfish-resources_1_5.dtd)

Request you to merge the PR
Merging - thank you.
Any objections? I would like to merge this.

Please no. While it might be acceptable to do things like this in some cases, I think it would require a good argument on why that's the best solution. In this case, there appear to be at least two alternative fix candidates:
-LineDocumentUtils.getWordEnd apparently returns an offset that is beyond the document's length, so that might be fixed/changed to not do that. Probably simple, and while it might need some more double-checking, probably the best solution/fix.
-EditorCaret.mouseDragged could replace:
offset = LineDocumentUtils.getWordEnd(lineDoc, offset);
with something like:
offset = Math.min(LineDocumentUtils.getWordEnd(lineDoc, offset), c.getDocument().getLength())
but that feels somewhat hacky (i.e. why getWordEnd even returned the offset that is too high), but would still be better than catching the BadLocationException.

So, this will mean some usages won't be found (more or less silently), which does not feel right. I tried a few simple cases (including the platform/core.multitabs), although on a dev build of JDK 12, and didn't see the problem. So I wonder what is the reproducible testcase, so that we can find out what's the issue.

I believe it should be possible to re-write the search for the constructor to only work over trees (basically, do classTree.getMembers() and search for the constructor); it might be tricky to determine which of the members is the constructor, but should be possible. (TreeUtilities.isSynthetic in the worst case). Besides for potentially fixing this bug, it might also be somewhat faster.

For reference, the JVM default is documented here: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/technotes/guides/vm/gctuning/parallel.html#default_heap_size although it's still not clear enough for me...

This commit is an improvement versus the status quo, but how many machines with under 4GB of RAM use NetBeans? And for those over 4GB we ask the same 1GB like the JVM. It's a draw.

I think we should actually ask for more RAM compared to the default as we were too conservative.

Considering 8GB is not so rare nowadays on a machine, I think asking 50% of the memory with a cap at 4GB sounds much better.

If we apply this commit we lose a way to increase the max heap.

Thus, I vote not for removing our heuristics, but for asking for more compared to the JVM default.

The other problem is that we have no nice way of allowing the user to increase the max heap size. Somehow editing a deep .conf file doesn't seem very user friendly.

The documentation does not seem to be correct. From my machine:

```
matthias@athena:~$ java -version
java version "1.8.0_181"
Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_181-b13)
Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.181-b13, mixed mode)
matthias@athena:~$ java -XshowSettings 2>&1 | grep Heap
    Max. Heap Size (Estimated): 3.46G
matthias@athena:~$ 
matthias@athena:~$ bin/jdk-11/bin/java -version
openjdk version "11" 2018-09-25
OpenJDK Runtime Environment 18.9 (build 11+28)
OpenJDK 64-Bit Server VM 18.9 (build 11+28, mixed mode)
matthias@athena:~$ bin/jdk-11/bin/java -XshowSettings 2>&1 | grep Heap
    Max. Heap Size (Estimated): 3.89G
matthias@athena:~$ 
```

That is also verified by using JMX on a jrunscript session. The java.lang/Memory/HeapMemoryUsage shows a maximum HeapMemoryUsage of 4173332480.

Given, that the permanent generation was moved offheap, 1/4 of available ram sound like a reasonable size.

Well, I have a died thread on this on the mailing list: http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/netbeans-dev/201810.mbox/%3C8fb7cf19-c2d2-8147-a5c4-f5dcc84e0e80%40gmail.com%3E

I would favor the 25% as the JVM default, as it is often the case (at least for me) that you are running application servers databases an other IDE a resource hungry browser besides for NetBeans.
Anyway an option to select the JVM and the Max Heap Size shall be editable in the UI.

Strictly speaking, it's not possible to cache the image here, because we don't know what part of the "Component c" parameter's state the delegate's paintImage method might use. If said state changes, we'd have to invalidate the cache. Though the previous code didn't seem to care about this. There's also a fair bit of extra logic that would have to be added to check if the cache needs to be updated (comparing the FontRenderContext, ensuring thread-safety etc.). I figured the added complexity was not worth it, given that icon images (even HiDPI ones) are typically tiny. If you disagree, and think it's preferable to ignore the "Component c" state problem, I'm happy to add caching logic.

I can remove the deactivated debugging lines.

Indeed, the documentation is confusing. So, Java max heap is by default 25% of RAM on systems with over 4GB or RAM, which sounds OK to me.

Since the default sounds better now, +1 on this PR.

You probably know more about this area than me. There are a few aspects in my mind here:

* generally speaking icons won't move around displays with different scalings. So, it seems better to always cache and risk a bad icon when move than to never cache and pay some computational cost for every repaint. Not caching is correct, but is it really worth the price? (Then again, we have no measurement of the actual cost).

* the old (existing?) NetBeans code cared a lot about image caching, so I assume they had some metrics for this fear.

* there is something odd about the design too. So `DisabledIcon` wraps an `Icon`. But then during paint time: it creates a temporary image, paints the icon there, creates a disables *image* then paints that. Considering icons are the closest we have to vector graphics (ie. non-raster) in AWT/Swing, this roundtrip is annoying to me. I guess I'm surprised we can't do `RGBImageFilter` at Graphics2D level, like we can do a `setTransform`.

I added another commit that implements caching. That should at least preserve the previous performance-related behavior.

As far as I know there is no way around the need for a BufferedImage here.

It seems that there is no objection. So let's merge this.

The change creates three new modules and puts them into `extra` cluster: `libs.javafx.linux`, `libs.javafx.macosx`,  `libs.javafx.win`. These modules are wrappers around [OpenJFX](http://openjfx.io) maven JARs, however none of the modules contains the GPL licensed JARs by itself - it just references them and the plugin manager downloads them directly to the user when installing them.

As such it is important for the modules to not be present in the final ZIP and only available from an update center. Putting the modules into `extra` cluster manages the first part - they aren't in the ZIP. To make them available from an update center this change introduces a "local" update center that holds the (empty) NBM files. Ready for install at any time.

The changes were tested on JDK8 and JDK11. On JDK8 only `nb-javac` is downloaded. On JDK11 one can continue without downloading anything, or download both: the `nb-javac` as well as appropriate `openjfx` library.

Please review, approve, integrate. Thanks in advance @jlahoda, @sdedic, @svenreimers!

@Chris2011 well, it doesn't solve the problem you think it does, as you can already use PNG in place of any GIF. You sure the splashscreen is actually a GIF?!  And while I agree with @sdedic that hiding PNG as GIF is a horrible hack, it doesn't seem worth having a negative performance impact to fix it?!

SVG would be great, but ideally requires being able to plugin in to the image resolution code - let's talk on mailing list, because I would love to work on this.

Ok, but afaik, there was some exception after using a PNG or a GIF, instead of another format. I think it should be similar. SVG would be great but someone said, that this is not possible with normal Swing AFAIK.

Anyway, what I thought is to change everything where it makes sense (maybe 80-90%) to PNG instead of using GIF. And AFAIK yes the splashscreen is GIF instead of PNG, this is why the quality is a bit poor. But I'm not 100% sure, @geertjanw asked for the GIF for the SplashScreen and for a PNG for the about dialog or vice versa. can't remember it exactly.
And yes should be discussed on the mailing list :).
